FAQ.question: What is an Agricultural Sale Deed?
FAQ.answer: It is a legally registered document that transfers ownership of agricultural land from the seller to the buyer and serves as primary proof of title.

FAQ.question: What details are required to download an agricultural sale deed?
FAQ.answer: You only need the Tahsildar & Jt. Registrar Office, Document Number, and Registration Year.

FAQ.question: Is a Sale Deed enough for proof of ownership?
FAQ.answer: It is the primary document, but you should also verify mutation status, survey records, tax receipts, and EC history for complete validation.

FAQ.question: What other documents should be checked with an agricultural sale deed?
FAQ.answer: Survey records, mutation/Khata, Encumbrance Certificate, prohibited land status, tax receipts, and farmer passbook or revenue extracts where applicable.

FAQ.question: What is the difference between an Agreement of Sale and a Sale Deed?
FAQ.answer: An Agreement of Sale is a promise to sell; ownership is transferred only when a Sale Deed is registered at the Sub-Registrar Office.

FAQ.question: How can I verify the authenticity of the sale deed?
FAQ.answer: You can cross-check registration details on government portals, match EC history, and verify survey and mutation records.

FAQ.question: Why is registration required for agricultural land sale?
FAQ.answer: Registration makes the transfer legally enforceable and ensures government records reflect the new ownership.

FAQ.question: Can JaaGa provide certified copies of agricultural sale deeds?
FAQ.answer: Yes. You can request certified copies through JaaGa, and they are sourced directly from government offices.

FAQ.question: Does the sale deed include survey boundaries?
FAQ.answer: It includes survey numbers and extent, but detailed boundaries may require survey maps or FMB extracts.

FAQ.question: Is the data provided by JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. All sale deed data is retrieved from official government registrations and is not altered or recreated.
